introduction.p: Logarithms can sometimes be the source of much turmoil and angst to students. To some members of the English department, the word logarithms is used as a joke to respond to something that is confusing, Is that like logarithms? (laughter ensues).
But you will not have these issues, because logarithms are not bad, they're just spelled that way. Remember this: A logarithm is an exponent.

This activity is an introduction to logarithms and the logarithmic function. Since logarithms are exponents, it is a good idea to review some key properties of exponents, particularly negative and fractional exponents.

subsection.title: Review of Exponents
subsection.p: Remember that negative exponents mean reciprocal and fractional exponents mean roots.

statement.p: For additional practice and information follow this link to Khan Academy.

subsection.p: In the next set of exercises, practice the idea of using the power (exponent) of a number (the base) to get a particular result.

subsection.title: The Meaning of a Logarithm
subsection.p: Earlier in the study of exponential functions, we solved exponential equations graphically. Another way to solve an exponential equation is to guess-and-check. It is not a very efficient method, but in this case it may help clarify what a logarithm does.

statement.p: Use the equation y=^x to complete the table.

subsection.p: Notice that for each ordered pair, we could say 10 raised to the (input) power is (output). For instance, 10 raised to the -1 power is \frac{1}{10}=0.1
In the following exercise, our goal is to find the power of 10 that equals 36. In other words, to solve the equation 10^x=36 in which we want to know What power of 10 gives us 36.
From the results in the previous table we realize the exponent is not going to be an integer like 0 or 1 or 2. It will have to be some decimal value.

statement.p: We wish to solve the equation ^x=. To that end, you make the table:
The result we want, y= is between what two outputs in the table?
Therefore, the exponent must be \lt x \lt
We can pick a number between 1 and 2 like x=1.5 to see how close the result is to 36
Since the exponent x=1.5 is too small, how about x=1.6?
Since the exponent x=1.6 is too big we now know a better answer is 1.5 \lt x \lt 1.6
To get better accuracy, we need to keep guessing. As we suspected, guess-and-check is a slow, clunky way of solving equations.

solution.p: Therefore, the exponent must be \lt x \lt
This means x=1.5 is too small, so trying x=1.6 gives:
Since the exponent x=1.6 is too big, we now know a better answer is that 1.5 \lt x \lt 1.6

subsection.p: Next, we can try a graphical approach.

introduction.p: So far the Geogebra graphing tool has been sufficient in helping us create and manipulate graphs. However, to get more accuracy in our solution we can use another free, online graphing tool, Desmos. Although you may also use your graphing calculator.

statement.p: We wish to solve the equation ^x=. To that end, examine the graph:
Click on this link to Desmos.com and solve the equation graphically.
To three decimal places, what is the value of x that solves the equation ^x=?
Use the same method to solve ^x=

subsection.p: As you experienced in the last two exercises, different powers of 10 give us different results. In fact, we can get any positive result we want using only powers of 10 (or any positive base for that matter).
Since logarithms are exponents, then finding a logarithm is like asking:

p.q: What power of (choose a base) do I need to get (whatever result you want)?

statement.p: In English we can ask an exponential question and get a logarithm answer:

blockquote.p: Exponential question, What power of 3 gives you 81?
Logarithm answer, The power of 3 that gives you 81 is the 4th power. (Because 3^{4}=81)

statement.p: In Math that same question and answer look like this:

assemblage.p: log_a(b) represents the power we raise the base a to, in order to get b.

subsection.p: The structure of a logarithm is that it must tell the reader the base number and it has to state what value you are trying to get.
Base 10 means you are using powers of 10 as in 10^{x}. Base 3 means you are using powers of 3 as in 3^{x} etc.
Below is a table that shows how Exercise, which used base 10, looks when written in both English and Math.

row.cell: The power of 10 that gives you 36
The power of 10 that gives you 0.6

subsection.p: For example, \log_{10}(100) means The power of 10 that gives you 100.

statement.p:
The power of 10 that gives you 100 is written in math as:
\log(100)
With that in mind, what power of 10 gives you 100?

solution.p: This is because the power of 10 that will give is .

subsection.p: The math word log is short for logarithm. It means log base 10. But we can use any positive number as a base, so \log_b means log base b.
Since \log is base 10 (powers of 10) we technically should write \log_{10}, but base 10 is so often used, we leave out the 10 for convenience.
Another commonly used logarithm is base e. It's called the natural logarithm and is written \ln. Again, technically we should write \log_e, but we write \ln for convenience.
All other logarithms are written in standard format. The base, b, indicates what number is being multiplied over and over. So if 2 is the base, we write \log_2 which indicates powers of 2.

statement.p: How would you say each expression below using logarithms?

li.p: The power of that gives you

subsection.p: At this point of the activity we should be able to estimate the value of a given logarithmic expression with the understanding that a logarithm is just an exponent.

statement.p: For each logarithm expression below, estimate the result with an integer that is just below and an integer that is just above the result.
For example, \log(36) is between 1 and 2 because 36 is between 10^1 and 10^2.
Remember, a logarithm is an exponent.

subsection.title: Domain of a Logarithmic Function
subsection.p: Try to evaluate \log(-100) on your calculator. Your calculator should read error or quit or something indicating it cannot complete the calculation. To understand why this is happening, we could try writing out the meaning of \log(-100) in English.

statement.p: Translate the math expression below into what it would mean in English (even if the statement ultimately makes no sense).
The power of that gives you .

solution.p: The power of that gives you .

subsection.p: If you have a bunch of positive 10s then how many do you have to multiply to get a negative 100? Of course, you can't get a negative result if you only have positive 10s! You would need at least one negative 10 and you don't have any.

Try to evaluate \log(0) on your calculator. Your calculator should read error or quit or something indicating it cannot complete the calculation. To understand why this is happening, we could again write out the meaning of \log(0) in English.

statement.p: Translate the math expression below into what it would mean in English (even if the statement ultimately makes no sense).
The power of that gives you .

solution.p: The power of that gives you .

subsection.p: If you have a bunch of positive 10s then how many do you have to multiply to get 0 as a result? Of course, you can't get 0 as the result if you only have positive 10s! At least one factor would have to be 0, but all you have is 10's.

It turns out that the \log function (with any base b \gt 0) is not defined for inputs that are less than or equal to 0. Therefore the domain of the \log function (with any base b \gt 0) is only positive numbers.

statement.p: Use an inequality or an interval to complete the statement below:
The domain of the \log_b(x) function (with any base b \gt 0) is .

solution.p: The domain is x>0, which can also be written as (0,\infty).

subsection.title: The Range of a Logarithmic Function
subsection.p: Earlier we used graphs to answer the questions:
We answered the questions using logarithm statements: \log(36) \approx 1.556 and \log(0.6) \approx -0.222
Notice with base 10, we can use positive or negative exponents to get any positive result we want.
Do you want to get a result of 36? Use a power of about 1.556 as in 10^{1.556} \approx 36
Do you want to get a result of 0.6? Use a power of about -0.222 as in 10^{-0.222} \approx 0.6.
Remember that logarithms are exponents, and clearly an exponent can be positive, negative or zero.
Logarithms tell you the power you need to get a particular result. You input the result you want, the function tells you the exponent you need. The exponent is the output.

statement.p: What power of 10 gives you 1?

solution.p: The power of 10 that gives 1 is 0.

subsection.p: Given an input from the domain of a logarithmic function, the range can be positive, negative or zero. In fact, the range is all real numbers.

assemblage.p: If \log_{b}(x)=y then y can be any real number.

subsection.title: The Graph of a Logarithmic Function
subsection.p: Our discoveries about the domain and range of a logarithmic function lead us to wonder what the graph might look like. So far we know:

li.p: The domain is limited to only positive input values. So there should be some kind of boundary that separates the inputs the function can use from the ones the function cannot use.
For a base greater than 1, the bigger the result we want to get, the bigger the exponent needs to be. So the logarithm should be an increasing function.
The output can be any real number, so we expect the graph to exist both above and below the horizontal axis as well as having a horizontal intercept.

The input is the value you are trying to get. The output is the exponent you need to put on 2 to get the desired input.
For each value of x, ask yourself What power of 2 gives me the x value? The answer to this question goes in the output box.

statement.p: \log_{2} is Log base 2 which means Powers of 2.
The input is the value you are trying to get. The output is the exponent you need to get the desired input.
For each value of x, ask yourself What power of 2 gives me the x value? the answer to this question goes in the output box.
Remember negative exponents mean reciprocal.
Drag the points to the coordinates from your table. The graph will become viewable when the points are placed correctly.

Notice the closer the input x is to zero, the further down the function goes. The value x=0 is not in the domain of the function, but we can get infinitely close to x=0. As a result the function will go down infinitely as we approach x=0
The graph shows a logarithmic function for which you can adjust the base and the input values.
For instance you can set the base to 2 and the input to 4 so you can evaluate \log_{2}(4)

li.p: What power of 4 that gives you 0.8?
What power of 10 that gives you 1?
The power of 10 that gives you \log(1)=

statement.p: Notice the graph only appears to the right of the y-axis. This is because the y-axis is a vertical line at x=0 and we know the domain of a logarithmic function is x \gt 0.
The y-axis is a vertical asymptote. It represents that the outputs increase toward infinity as x decreases toward zero.
Notice the graph has negative and positive outputs and zero output. Those represent the range of the function.
Finally, notice that the bigger the base value, the more closely the graph hugs the horizontal axis

introduction.p: In order for this part of the activity to make sense, we must remember what a base and an exponent are. Remember in the expression b^x, b is the base and x is the exponent. The exponent literally counts how many times you multiplied the base. For instance b^7 means \overbrace{b\cdot b\cdot b\cdot b\cdot b\cdot b\cdot b}^{7\text{ times}}.

subsubsection.title: Definition: A logarithm is an exponent
subsubsection.p:
An exponential equation
b^{y}=x
can be rewritten as a logarithmic equation.

statement.p:
An exponential equation
b^{y}=x
can be rewritten as a logarithmic equation.

\log_b(x)=y
the logarithmic equation means:
The power of that gives you is .
Rewrite each logarithmic equation as an exponential equation then evaluate your exponential expression to determine the value of x.

li.p: \log_{2}(x)=3 as an exponential equation is x=
\log_{2}(x)=-1 as an exponential equation is x=
\log_{2}(x)=0 as an exponential equation is x=

subsubsection.title: Rule: The Log of a product
subsubsection.p: We start with a very simple property of exponents: x^a\cdot x^b=x^{a+b}. When you multiply numbers of the same base you add the exponents.

statement.p: Simplify and rewrite the product ^\cdot ^ as one exponential expression.
^\cdot ^= .
Check that this is valid by using a calculator to find:
and checking that the first two multiply to the third.

subsubsection.p: Now let's take some obvious information that you already concluded above to discover a not-so-obvious property of logarithms.

statement.p: What power of 2 gives you 128?

subsubsection.p:
Now you can write the equation \log_{2}(8\cdot16)=\log_{2}(128) as
\log_{2}(8\cdot16)=7\text{.}

Notice on the left side of the equation:
There are 3 factors of 2 in 8. That's why \log_{2}(8)=3.
There are 4 factors of 2 in 16. That's why \log_{2}(8)=4.
So the simple equation 7=3+4, can be written using logarithms
7=3+4 7=\log_{2}(8)+\log_{2}(16) \log_{2}(128)=\log_{2}(8)+\log_{2}(16) \log_{2}(8 \cdot 16)=\log_{2}(8)+\log_{2}(16)

statement.p: Can you evaluate \log_{3}(243) without a calculator? Of course you can.
What power of 3 gives you 9? \log_{3}(9)=
What power of 3 gives you 27? \log_{3}(27)=
Therefore \log_{3}(243)=

subsubsection.title: Rule: Bring Down the Exponent
subsubsection.p: We start with something obvious. You already know that instead of writing 8+8+8+8 you could just write 4\cdot8.
Maybe you never thought about it, but multiplication is just repeated addition. It's a shortcut way to write the same thing added over and over.
On the other hand, exponents are just repeated multiplication. Exponents are a shortcut way to write the same thing multiplied over and over.

Since both shortcuts must give the same answer, we get
\log\mathopen{}\left(8^4\right)\mathclose{}=\log(8)+\log(8)+\log(8)+\log(8)

statement.p:
Multiplication is shorthand for repeated addition. So, adding Q four times is
Q+Q+Q+Q=4 \cdot Q
Use the same shorthand to rewrite the repeated sum
\log(8)+\log(8)+\log(8)+\log(8)= (hint: how many times is \log(8) repeated?)
So here is the big finale:
In general

subsubsection.title: Rule: Log of a Quotient
subsubsection.p: You will discover this rule by using the two rules you already know.

statement.p: Consider the expression \log\mathopen{}\left(\frac{A}{B}\right)\mathclose{}
Use a negative exponent on B to rewrite the fraction inside the log function as a product.
The right side of the equation is now a product of two values.
Use the rule \log(A\cdot B)=\log(A)+\log(B) to rewrite the right side as the sum of two log terms.

The second term on the right side has a value with a negative exponent. Use the rule \log_{b}(N^{x})=x \log_{b}(N), where b>0, to bring down the negative exponent. Now the second term is simply adding a negative. Rewrite the right side after the negative exponent is brought down in front of the log term.
The entire right side can now be written as a difference (subtraction).
